posts.title: IdeArtist - A Creative Prompt Tool
posts.content:
Link to Prototype

This project was completed for a Human Computer Interaction (HCI) course over seven weeks. The purpose was to develop a high-fidelity prototype and understand the full iterative design process by implementing it hands on.

Below is an example of some of the study goals we wrote and carried out.

In each step, from storyboarding to wireframing to prototyping, we underwent various evaluations from others (heuristic evaluations, think-alouds, semi-structured interviews, etc.)

Here is a full layout of all the final prototype screens.

You can also watch a sped up video walking through the prototype here

posts.title: Customizable Browser Homepage
posts.description: A homepage dashboard built in NodeJS and Express, with custom settings saved for users (authenticated via Github OAuth) in MongoDB
posts.excerpt: This application was developed as part of a final project for a webware course with three other group members. Link to Github Repo
posts.content:
This application was developed as part of a final project for a webware course with three other group members. Link to Github Repo

Description: A browser home page application that has customizable boxes/categories that users can fill in to have bookmarks, notes, tasks, and images. The idea is that the user will open their browser and use this page to start their day/work/session. The user will be able to log in so that their content persists between sessions. This application is targeted at users who use their computers on a daily basis and would like a customizable web browsing experience. The application will make use of a database in MongoDB to store the homepage layout, input, preferences, etc.

Video Walkthrough

posts.title: Meal Planner App
posts.excerpt: This app was built with two other group members as part of a final project for Mobile & Ubiquitous Computing. We developed the application in Kotlin/Java, using Android studio to test functionality.
posts.content:
This app was built with two other group members as part of a final project for Mobile & Ubiquitous Computing. We developed the application in Kotlin/Java, using Android studio to test functionality. 

The purpose of this app is to help groups of people living together with meal planning and grocery shopping.

One of the main features allows users to schedule meals for the week and select recipes for each scheduled meal. The user can add people/create a group for each scheduled meal. 

Below is a basic structure of the entire app flow.

posts.title: Code Crafters Research & Design
posts.excerpt: Code Crafters is an ongoing research project that investigates the relationship between quilting and computational thinking.
posts.content:
Code Crafters is an ongoing research project that investigates the relationship between quilting and computational thinking.

In this project, I paired with a PhD student conducting user research on the Code Crafters generative quilt design software. We ran multiple pilot studies with people who identitied as “crafters” to understand their learning process as they navigated the software.

With the data from our pilot studies, we brainstormed several design themes for our learning goals and future direction of the software. From there, we developed simple wireframes and then a more high-fidelity prototype, which we will continue to use as we start to make changes to the software itself.

posts.title: Wine Quality Data Analysis
posts.excerpt: This project was completed with another group partner as part of our Machine Learning course. The goal was to analyze a public dataset to determine different components that affect the quality of red wine compared to white wine. We used Python as our main tool to run various models on the dataset, create data visualizations, and extract the most relevant predictors.
posts.content:
This project was completed with another group partner as part of our Machine Learning course. The goal was to analyze a public dataset to determine different components that affect the quality of red wine compared to white wine. We used Python as our main tool to run various models on the dataset, create data visualizations, and extract the most relevant predictors.

Our various models are listed below, with the smallest Mean Squared Error in green, and vice versa for red.

As can be seen, the decision tree classifier was the best model for red wine while random forest classification was best for white wine.

From our analysis, we found that alcohol was by far as the most significant predictor of red wine quality, followed by volatile acidity. On the other hand, we found alcohol and density to be the most important predictors of white wine quality.

For further details on our analysis, view the full report here with all of our findings.

posts.title: Developing a Virtual Tour for the Santa Elena Reserve
posts.excerpt: My social science capstone or IQP was at the Monteverde, Costa Rica project center, with the Santa Elena Cloud Forest Reserve (SER) as our sponsor.  As a whole, the SER plays a fundamental role within the local community, receiving nearly 40,000 visitors annually. But with COVID-19, there were serious economic repercussions for tourism-reliant communities like Monteverde; so our project work over the course of seven weeks was to create a virtual tour of the reserve to expand their outreach and promote further donations in the future.
posts.content:
My social science capstone or IQP was at the Monteverde, Costa Rica project center, with the Santa Elena Cloud Forest Reserve (SER) as our sponsor.  As a whole, the SER plays a fundamental role within the local community, receiving nearly 40,000 visitors annually. But with COVID-19, there were serious economic repercussions for tourism-reliant communities like Monteverde; so our project work over the course of seven weeks was to create a virtual tour of the reserve to expand their outreach and promote further donations in the future.

We mainly designed our virtual tour based on data collected from past visitors, tour guides, and experts of the reserve - and as we developed the tour, we sent out drafts and collected survey feedback from users on social media like Instagram to identify possible areas of improvement.

We designed our tour using Google Street View to capture 360 shots at different locations. For the virtual tour itself, we used a free, open-source software called Lapentor so that our sponsor could continue to add to the tour in the future.

​​​​

By the end, we hopefully provided the SER with a tour that highlights their best features and helps the reserve stand out as a unique attraction with its online presence.

Click here to see a video of the tour walkthrough, and here to read more about our project!

All credit for pictures of the reserve goes to our sponsor Walter Bello

posts.title: Small Business Digitization Services
posts.excerpt: Small Business Digitization Services is an initiative launched by WPI’s Business School to help small business owners maintain a digital presence throughout the pandemic and beyond. WPI Students pair up with different clients to address their business needs - for example, updating a storefront, improving SEO, etc.
posts.content:
Small Business Digitization Services is an initiative launched by WPI’s Business School to help small business owners maintain a digital presence throughout the pandemic and beyond. WPI Students pair up with different clients to address their business needs - for example, updating a storefront, improving SEO, etc. 

So far I have worked on a few different projects. One is with a client, Judy Faust, who is promoting her local musician friend John Mariano’s music. Together we have worked on monthly campaigns/newsletters and discussed various strategies such as YouTube performance livestreams for attracting an online audience.

Another e-commerce project I have worked on with two other students is helping a local business, Moonwater Elixirs. Our client wanted to evaluate/update her Shopify website as well as improve SEO for different products. We as a team helped refurbish different aspects, such as navigation, product pages, review sections, etc.

posts.title: Improving Fastly's HTTP Load Testing Tools
posts.excerpt: My senior capstone was a fourteen-week long project working with a Silicon Valley company partnered with WPI. As a team of three, we worked with the CDN company Fastly to develop an improved load testing tool to suit their needs and replicate specific scenarios with issues they were facing in production.
posts.content:
My senior capstone was a fourteen-week long project working with a Silicon Valley company partnered with WPI. As a team of three, we worked with the CDN company Fastly to develop an improved load testing tool to suit their needs and replicate specific scenarios with issues they were facing in production.

As part of our project, we extended an open-source load testing tool K6 to include a force HTTP/1 feature, which we were eventually able to merge into the official project! This was definitely valuable getting to see the entire approval process and what is generally required for complex tools like these.

After finding K6, we also integrated new programs/features into a Fastly-specific wrapper program to address different limitations of their old load-testing tool - for example, generating TLS handshakes with the tool TLS-Perf, and creating secure connections to remote hosts via bastions.

One job I focused on was writing a program to generate load against Fastly’s target server via idle TCP connections. There were various aspects of this task that were previously unfamiliar to me - using GoLang for the first time, its vast package library (particularly the network I/O package), and concurrency with goroutines.

Although working through these issues involved a slight learning curve at first, I got a lot of guidance and advise from our Fastly mentors, and by the end I definitely felt I had a solid grasp of the program! I also got additional experience from problems that were uncovered in the process - for example, when we faced an issue with insufficient file descriptors, I had the opportunity to learn about the whole concept of ephemeral ports and accessing network interfaces, which I didn’t know much about previously.

At the end of the project, our project sponsor helped us actually test the program against Fastly’s servers to replicate those original production scenarios, and we got to see some really interesting output via Grafana network dashboards as seen below. It was really cool to see our work get integrated into Fastly’s software stack and prove useful for them in replicating various production scenarios!

content_blocks.content_html:
I am a senior undergraduate studying Computer Science at Worcester Polytechnic Institute. Right now my aim is to continue with my education as part of WPI's combined BS/MS program so I can hopefully earn my Master's by Fall 2022! I've had experience in different areas throughout my studies, but my main research interests are in digital medicine/healthcare and human-computer interaction.
Career-wise, I've worked mostly with various enterprise applications and full-stack development/design using a few different technologies - Angular, React, NodeJS, Java/SpringBoot, etc. Recently I've also worked extensivly with GoLang, specifically with its network/HTTP features for load testing.
On the side, I also really enjoy making artwork and designs, which you can check out on my Art & NFTs page!

Ut in geometria, prima si dederis, danda sunt omnia. Longum est enim ad omnia respondere, quae a te dicta sunt. Id quaeris, inquam, in quo, utrum respondero, verses te huc atque illuc necesse est. Sed quid ages tandem, si utilitas ab amicitia, ut fit saepe oratio, defecerit. content_blocks.title: Hi! I'm Saniya Syeda
content_blocks.description_html: I am an undergraduate student at Worcester Polytechnic Institute studying Computer Science. On this site you can check out the main projects and research I've completed as a student, as well as some of my artwork/NFTs!

content_blocks.description: Below is a compilation of all the different project work I've done over the course of my undergraduate career!

projects.title: Tiny Dino
projects.subtitle: NFT - Digital Art
projects.content:
OpenSea
RedBubble

“Tiny Dino” is something I created after taking my very first Graphic Design class in college! I had just learned the bare essentials of Adobe Illustrator and Photoshop, so I attempted to do as much as I could with my free trial software in the meantime 😁

Original Sketch:

projects.title: Hamlet Cover
projects.subtitle: NFT - Digital Art
projects.content:
OpenSea
Redbubble

This is a work I made for a final project in my first Graphic Design class. We had to choose a piece of literature and design our own cover spread for it, so this piece is just the artwork I designed to go on the title page. The whole process you can see below.

Here is the original sketch idea drawn on paper:

I then scanned this into Photoshop to trace over it digitally, and finally uploaded the vector to Adobe InDesign. Here is the full book cover spread:

projects.title: Flower Sketch
projects.subtitle: NFT - Digital Art
projects.content:
OpenSea
Redbubble

This is a design I made for my Humanities capstone project, “Illustrating Fiction,” in which we created illustrations to accompany short stories and did our best to incorporate all thematic elements.

The story I had was called “The Bouquet” by Kate McIntyre, which is about a meticulous to-be bride who is searching for her perfect wedding bouquet but is always unsatisfied. She visits an old florist’s shop, who finally is able to help her find what she’s looking for, though in an unconventional way. You can read the full story here.

Below you can see some more illustrations I made for the final project, both paper sketch and digital.
